title: Ticket #4499: Potential null pointer dereference in InitCommandSocket
description:
Coverity correctly points out that InitCommandSockets (/src/condor_daemon_core.V6/daemon_core.cpp around line 9676) implies that it's valid to pass in a sock_pair with a null ReliSock. If that's the case, later code dereferences it in unsafe ways. There are no known cases where this actively happens, but it is a landmine that could surprise future code. 

  9734                // Ensure we have a socket, setsockopt doesn't work otherwise.
 At conditional (1): "rsock" taking the false branch.
 CID 10511: Dereference after null check (FORWARD_NULL)
 Comparing "rsock" to null implies that "rsock" might be null.
  9735                if(rsock) {
  9736                        if(!assign_sock(proto, rsock, fatal)) { return false; }
  9737                }
 At conditional (2): "ssock" taking the true branch.
  9738                if(ssock) {
 At conditional (3): "!assign_sock(proto, ssock, fatal)" taking the false branch.
  9739                        if(!assign_sock(proto, ssock, fatal)) { return false; }
  9740                }
  9741
  9742#if defined ( WIN32 )
  9743                /** To better match the *nix semantics of SO_REUSEADDR we
  9744                        enable MSs SO_EXCLUSIVEADDRUSE option, which prohibits
  9745                        multiple process/identities/etc. from binding to the
  9746                        same address (which is just crazy behaviour!).
  9747
  9748                        For further details refer to ticket #288. */
  9749                so_option = SO_EXCLUSIVEADDRUSE;
  9750#endif
  9751
  9752                        // Set options on this socket, SO_REUSEADDR, so that
  9753                        // if we are binding to a well known port, and we
  9754                        // crash, we can be restarted and still bind ok back
  9755                        // to this same port. -Todd T, 11/97
 Passing null variable "rsock" to function "Sock::setsockopt(int, int, void const *, int)", which
dereferences it. [show details]
  9756                if( !rsock->setsockopt(SOL_SOCKET, so_option,
  9757                                                           (char*)&on, sizeof(on)) ) {
  9758                        if (fatal) {

Proposed fix: restructure the code so that all interactions with rsock occur inside of the "if(rsock)" test. For symmetry, do so for ssock as well.
